awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study the quantum mechanical behavior of atoms in one dimensional (1D) gases.  This is important because 1D gases are one of the few many-body systems for which exact quantitative predictions can be made about their quantum states.  In comparison, most other quantum many-body systems are not "integrable," and therefore are much more challenging to describe.  For this project, ultracold atoms will be prepared and then confined in 1D traps using laser light.  The atomic momentum distributions in these 1D gases will be precisely measured under a variety of conditions, and this will serve as a benchmark test for advanced theoretical approaches that are being developed to understand many-body quantum systems.  This project is also designed to observe quantum many-body phenomena such as "dynamical fermionization" and "prethermalization."  These experiments will motivate new theoretical approaches that will also be relevant for nuclear and condensed matter physics, and will lead to a deeper understanding of quantum many-body phenomena such as superconductivity, magnetism, and quantum information processing.  Students working on this project will learn advanced atomic physics research techniques that will prepare them for careers in academia or high tech industry.

This team will work on three sets of measurements related to the momentum distributions of 1D Bose gases, using a technique that is dramatically more precise than previous approaches. The first set of measurements will be of equilibrium momentum distributions with intermediately and strongly coupled gases, for a range of temperatures. These will be compared to new theoretical calculations. Any disagreement would indicate that the 1D gases do not have a thermal distribution, despite their extremely gentle preparation starting from equilibrated 3D gases. The second set of measurements will entail the first observation of dynamical fermionization, where the initially bosonic momentum distribution of a Tonks-Girardeau gas transforms into that of a non-interacting Fermi gas, thus directly revealing the underlying conserved quantities in this system. The third set of measurements will measure the early stages of prethermalization after a quantum quench. The quench will be a Bragg scattering pulse, and the part of the ensuing evolution that is related to the point contact interactions is much faster than typical evolution in a trap. Comparisons with recently developed theory will be made. For the latter two sets of the measurements it is beyond existing theoretical methods to perform these dynamical calculations in the intermediate coupling regime. But the investigators propose to perform the experiments there as well, thus setting benchmarks for theorists to work toward.

por.por_cntn:
We have experimentally studied one-dimensional (1D) Bose gases by trapping ultra-cold 87Rb atoms in a 2D optical lattice. The 2D optical lattice creates a bundle of tube-shaped atom traps, where within each tube all transverse motion is frozen out.  These interacting many-body systems have the special property of being nearly integrable, which implies that have a large set of extra conserved quantities. In the first part of this work, we observed the phenomenon of ?dynamical fermionization?, whereby the momentum distribution of a strongly interacting Bose gas evolves into the momentum distribution of an identically trapped non-interacting Fermi gas. For the first time, this experimentally illustrated an aspect of these gases that is central to its theoretical description. We also demonstrated another, somewhat related phenomenon, Bose-Fermi oscillations, in which a breathing oscillation is set in motion in the 1D gases, and the momentum distribution oscillates between bosonic and fermionic twice each breathing period.

The observation of dynamical fermionization showed that we have experimental access to the ?rapidities?, which are the momenta of the quasiparticles that arise due to the interparticle interactions. Since it is particles that are ultimately measured, not emergent quasiparticles, rapidity distributions were considered to be a useful theoretical bookkeeping tool, not a measurable quantity. But when a gas is allowed to expand in an axially flat 1D trap, the interactions eventually decrease enough that the quasiparticles become the bare particles. Since the rapidities are conserved during the expansion, after expansion the momentum distribution of the bare particles are the distribution of rapidities. Using our new rapidity measurements for a wide range of coupling strengths, we were able to perform experiments with 1D gases out of equilibrium that could be compared to the new theory of generalized hydrodynamics (GHD).  The GHD description of our experiments turns out to be very accurate, validating the assumptions that underly the theory. When there are significant quantum correlations and entanglement in a system, no other theoretical approach has been able to study the evolution of a system as accurately for as long.

The study of out-of-equilibrium many-body quantum systems is a frontier of physics. These experiments, and their planned extensions, present a way forward for understanding a wide range of out-of-equilibrium quantum systems. Improved understanding can help guide the development of devices like quantum sensors, quantum computers and quantum simulators. A large array of technologies is brought to bear on these experiments, so the students that help design and run them are prepared for work in a wide range of scientific and technological pursuits.
